entry.title: Re: S4H: Print Freight Condition Total Value after Revisi...
entry.content:
Hello @TaniaTrindade 

what i understand purchasing/print form issue where the freight condition (header-level condition) is being recalculated or displayed incorrectly after partial GR and PO revision. My suggestion for you to do the following as mentioned below.

1. Print from Header Condition Directly
Adjust the PO print form (SmartForm / Adobe Form) logic to read the freight condition value from the header (EKPO/EKKO + KONV) instead of summing item-level distributed values. This way, the printout always shows the full freight cost (500 USD), regardless of GR status.

2. Use Condition Value (KONV)
In KONV, freight condition (e.g., FRB1, HD00, or custom Z-condition) is stored with header indicator. Fetch the KWERT (condition value) for the freight condition at header level. Ensure the print program doesn’t filter by open items only.

3. Custom Logic in Print Program
Enhance the PO output program (usually MEDRUCK or custom ZMEDRUCK) to, check if the condition is header-level. Print the total value (500 USD) instead of the distributed item values. This avoids dependency on GR status.

4. Alternative: Display Both
Some clients prefer showing, Total freight (header) = 500 USD then Remaining freight (open items) = 100 USD. This can be achieved by printing both header condition and distributed item condition values.

Identify the freight condition type in your system (check PO conditions tab). In the print form logic, if condition is header-level → print KONV-KWERT directly.
If condition is item-level → sum across items.
Test with revised PO where GR is partial to confirm.

Let me know if you need more clarity.

entry.title: Re: Can you remember the first time you heard of SAP
entry.content:
I was working as a production engineer in a manufacturing company, handling the production schedule, machine maintenance, and the assembly line workforce. When the management decided to implement SAP, I wasn’t familiar with it at all.

Consultants began visiting our factory to work with the core team and I was also involved in the discussions. I got a chance to speak to one of the consultants during a lunch break, and that conversation introduced me to SAP and its career possibilities. I realized that I could also be a part of this field.

Although I was interested, I was hesitant to take the leap because I didn’t come from a software background. I discussed it with one of my colleagues, who was initially unsure as well, but eventually we both decided to enroll and pursue a career in SAP.

entry.title: Re: ASM mode not calling custom request mapping for CCV2...
entry.content: The reason why the overridden request was not invoked was due to the request mapping not be the same. The OOTB endpoint used a request used a mapping of @GetMapping and the override used the older @RequestMapping. Once they were aligned the overridden request endpoint was invoked.

entry.title: Re: HU number is not distributed/EWM removing the HU number
entry.content:
Hi,

Have you checked the outbound queue (SMQ1) of your ERP system? Does the queue container have the HU data you are expecting?

Alternatively on the EWM side: have you checked the inbound queue (SMQ2)?

You can deregister the queues with SMQE or SMQR respectively to stop processing and then re-test to produce a new queue entry.

Regards Andreas

entry.title: @cap-js/mcp-server - Practical guide to get value on day on
entry.content:
Give your coding assistant instant, project‑aware knowledge of your CAP model and docs. With @cap-js/mcp-server, the assistant can look up entities, services, fields, and HTTP endpoints from your compiled CDS model and cross‑check official CAP docs, so it proposes the right code and changes in your editor.

Here's where I found this and would like to share with community - https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

  • Package: @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Command: cds-mcp
  • Tools: search_model (compiled CDS/CSN), search_docs (local CAP docs embeddings)
  • Works with MCP‑capable assistants in VS Code and other IDEs (e.g., Cline, Copilot Agent Mode, opencode)

Here’s the short version - just follow these 3 step

  1. Configure your IDE agent to start the server via npx:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}
  1. Add these rules to AGENTS.md so the assistant always uses the server correctly:
- You MUST search for CDS definitions, like entities, fields and services (which include HTTP endpoints) with cds-mcp, only if it fails you MAY read *.cds files in the project.
- You MUST search for CAP docs with cds-mcp EVERY TIME you create, modify CDS models or when using APIs or the `cds` CLI from CAP. Do NOT propose, suggest or make any changes without first checking it.
  1. Optional CLI smoke test:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Why you’ll love it

  • Stop guessing: Fuzzy‑search your compiled model for entities, services, elements, annotations, and endpoints.
  • Fewer mistakes: Suggestions are grounded in your actual model and verified against official CAP docs.
  • All local: Fast and private, perfect for day‑to‑day development.

IDE setup

VS Code - Cline extension

Settings example:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}

VS Code - GitHub Copilot Agent Mode (global mcp.json)

{
  "servers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {},
      "type": "stdio"
    },
    "inputs": []
  }
}

opencode

{
  "mcp": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "type": "local",
      "command": ["npx", "-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "enabled": true
    }
  }
}

Tip: Keep the server name “cds-mcp” in both your config and prompts so your assistant reliably calls it.

How to use it in your editor

Think “discover first, then change.” Ask your assistant to:

  • Discover model and endpoints

    • “Use cds‑mcp search_model to list all services and their HTTP endpoints. Then list entities with primary keys.”

  • Write a correct SELECT with expand

    • “Call cds‑mcp search_model for Books and its associations. Then, after checking CAP Node.js SELECT expand syntax via cds‑mcp search_docs, propose a handler that returns Books.title, Books.stock and expands auther.name.”

  • Generate precise OData URLs

    • “Find the service and endpoint for Books via search_model, then give me an OData V4 URL with $select=title,stock and $expand=author($select=name) plus a curl example.”

  • Safely change CDS/annotations

    • “Show docs for @Common.Label using cds‑mcp search_docs. Using search_model for Books, propose a minimal diff adding labels for title and stock. Include file paths.”

  • Plan a refactor

    • “We’re renaming Author to Writer. With cds‑mcp search_model, list affected entities, associations, services, and endpoints; propose a step‑by‑step PR plan.”

  • Implement an action/handler

    • “Find docs on defining and implementing a custom action in Node.js via cds‑mcp search_docs. Then sketch a minimal handler in srv/<service>.js with imports and input validation.”

Best practice: Ask the assistant to paste the search_model and search_docs results that justify any change.

CLI usage (optional but handy)

Install globally to test from your terminal:

npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Search your compiled model:
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
  • Search CAP documentation:
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Once the CLI works, your IDE agent can invoke the same tools automatically.

What the tools return

  • search_model

    • Names and kinds (entity, service, etc.)
    • Elements and annotations
    • File locations
    • HTTP endpoints where services are exposed

  • search_docs

    • The most relevant CAP documentation snippets for your query, based on local embeddings

Use both together: discover exact names/paths with search_model, confirm syntax and best practices with search_docs, then apply small, reviewable changes.

Tips for getting the most value

  • Start every task with search_model to avoid typos and stale assumptions.
  • Require docs‑backed edits: have the assistant run search_docs before proposing code.
  • Keep edits atomic: one focused change at a time, with file paths and minimal diffs.
  • Monorepo? Tell the assistant the CAP project folder to search.

Support and contribution

  • Issues and feature requests: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/issues
  • Security policy: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/security/policy
  • Code of Conduct: https://github.com/cap-js/.github/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
  • License and REUSE info: see LICENSE and https://api.reuse.software/info/github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

Now action - 

  • Add the MCP config, paste the two rules into AGENTS.md, and ask your assistant:
    “Discover all entities, keys, and endpoints with cds‑mcp search_model, verify the Node.js SELECT docs with cds‑mcp search_docs, then propose a minimal handler change for Books.”

    SAP Business Technology Platform  SAP Business AI SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: 新しい認定試験方式受けてみた
entry.content:
はじめに

先日アナウンスがあったとおり、SAPの認定試験が、これまでの選択式の試験からより実践的な試験に変更になるようです。
https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-learning-blog-posts/reimagining-certification-for-the-way-we-work-today/ba-p/14261141

現時点では一部の試験だけですが「2026年までに 、 すべてのSAP認定資格がこの新しい実践的な形式に移行します。」と記載されています。

  • 実技試験には2種類あるってことだけど、システム・ベース、シナリオ・ベースそれぞれどんな感じなの？
  • 英語で対応する必要がある？
  • オープンブック形式ってことだけど監督は全然されないってこと？

などが気になりつつ、さっそくチャレンジしてきました。

この記事は SAPアドベントカレンダー 2025 の 12月1日分の記事として執筆しています。

共通すること

  • 予約は不要になりました。いつでも好きなタイミングで受験できます。試験の監督官はつきません。
  • システムベースかシナリオベースかは、試験ごとにあらかじめ決まっています。おそらく、開発系の試験はシステムベース、アプリ系の試験はシナリオベースになるのだと思います。
  • このページをちゃんと読むと書いてありますが、Start Certification Examを押してから24hのカウントがあり、そのあとのステップに進むボタンを押してから2h（試験によっては3h）以内に終了する必要があります。システムベースだと、Access Practice Examをクリックしたタイミング、シナリオベースの場合、AIとのロールプレイにするかビデオ提出にするかを選択したタイミングです。
  • 各試験の案内ページのPrepare for Certification から行ける Learning Journey がためになるので、試験受けるか迷っていても、のぞいてみるのをおすすめします。たぶん、Learning Hub 持っていなくてもアクセスできます（ものによるのかも）

システム・ベース受けてみた（SAP Generative AI Developer）

1か月の無料トライアルを申し込んだときと同じような、IDのすでに決まった環境が割り当てられます。手順PDFがダウンロードできるので、その指示に従って環境に設定を行っていきます。

  • PDFは英語ですが、オープンブック形式ということは翻訳手段は何とでもなるのでハードルにはならないかと思います。
  • 各ステップの完了目安時間が示されているので、時間配分に気を付けながら進めていく必要があります。
  • Learning Journey の Practical Exercise を理解していれば、問題なく進められる内容でした。

シナリオ・ベース受けてみた（SAP Business Data Cloud）

スタートすると、「Yoodliを始める」というボタンとともに、カメラとマイクをONにしろ、と言われてビビりますが、回答内容を認識するためのものなので気楽にONにしてください。SAP Business Data Cloud の導入を検討しているユーザによる面接という体で、様々な質問をされるので、それに回答していきます。

  • AI、日本語で話してくれます！ので、もちろん日本語で答えれば大丈夫です。
  • 途中で通信状態が悪かったのか画面が固まってしまい進めずに焦りましたが、リロードしたら問題なく最初からやり直しになりました。（Don’t close this page と表示されていたのでビクビクしながら更新しましたが大丈夫でした）
  • オープンブック形式ということで、質問されてから色々見て回答を探しながら回答できます。そうすると、質問されてからかなり沈黙の時間が流れてしまいますが、そこは問題なさそうでした。ちゃんと回答を話し出すまで待ってくれます。
  • AIからの質問が終わると、スコアが表示されます。分野ごとに、どれくらいのレベルで回答できていたかが示されます。
  • このときに、AIの質問と自分の回答の文字起こしも表示されるので「文字起こしをコピー」ボタンでコピーしてどこかに保存することができます
  • 最初のスコアで合格ラインを越えられなかったのですが、時間内であれば最初からやり直すことができ、試験回数を追加で消費せずに合格することができました

おわりに

監督する人との会話がなく、部屋を見せる必要も身分証明書を出す必要もない試験、気楽でした！

試験の難易度的にも、かなり楽になってしまったのではないかと感じました。ここはこのまま行って大丈夫なのか、疑問が残ります。と言ってもシナリオベースで頑張ったつもりで67％のスコアしか取れなかったので、その領域についての知識の地図が頭にできてないと、厳しそうです。

以前の選択式のテストも、認定取ったからってその領域のコンサルとして明日から働けるか？はわからなかったわけで、「この実践テストを乗り越えたということは、何かを参照にしながらなら問題解決できますね」という方が目的にかなっているということなのかもしれません。

entry.title: Re: Serial Number Profile : Prefix (CBC activity 103636)
entry.content:
Hello @adrien_delanoe

The serialisation procedure you see in the WM view has nothing to do with the serial number prefix from SSCUI 103636, the serial number profile used in your inventory management, or equipment master serial number ranges. These are two different frameworks.

To answer your question, the serialisation procedure is used to defined whether EWM should enforce serialisation, at which step your system captures the serial numbers, whether thy are managed at storage bin level/stock level or for duplicate validation. This basically means that this field only controls your operational behaviour but not the number ranges.

However, the serial number profile SSCUI 103636 is the only part that affects the number created. Which also addresses what I clarified in my earlier answer. Meaning it only applies when you use EWM serialisation and not Inventory Management.

My initial guidance steps were focused on showing that the prefix only works inside EWM serialisation, the need to activate it for your material to be extended and to inform you that without it, your system will not use the warehouse serialisation setting, leading to prefix not appearing.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: RF Device printing issue -SAP WM Public Cloud 2508
entry.content:
Good day @SaleemSk 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

HU Shipping Label, Sources of Condition Parameters Used in Output Parameter Determination, Integration of Handling Units, SCM-EWM-PRN - Printing, Overview of Handling Units.

In summary, the current public cloud release does not enable the F1 Pack function to trigger HU label output. That is the reason why your system does not create the print queue when you press F1 pack, even though HU label printing works from the packing work center and the warehouse monitor.

In public cloud, HU label printing in these apps is not driven by the output parameter determination app. The system does not expose HU label output types there and there is no configuration or BAdI that allows you to automatically call HU label printing.

Due to public cloud’s clean-core restrictions, you may either print HU labels from the packing work center or warehouse monitor after your packing or you use RF printing transaction and trigger printing through the RF print function key and not through the F1 Pack.

Also considering the public cloud's clean-core principle restricts RF transaction modification, should you require automatic printing directly from F1 pack, you can only achieve that through an external or BTP-based extension.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition: A New Generation of Global Tax Compliance
Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition: A New Generation of Global Tax Compliance
entry.content:
In a world where governments are rapidly digitizing tax controls, companies must ensure real-time reporting, accurate e-invoicing, and seamless integration with local authorities. SAP has long supported these needs through its Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solution embedded in SAP S/4HANA.

As regulatory demands increase and cloud adoption accelerates, SAP introduced Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition—a next-generation, cloud-native platform designed to help enterprises respond faster, comply globally, and scale efficiently.

This article explains both solutions and highlights the key differences that set the Cloud Edition apart.

 

What Is SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)?

DRC is the integrated compliance framework within SAP S/4HANA, built to support:

  • Electronic invoicing (eDocuments)

  • Legal reporting (SAF-T, VAT, Intrastat, etc.)

  • Indirect tax submissions

  • Real-time government integrations

  • Audit and compliance workflows

DRC leverages SAP S/4HANA’s core capabilities, using:

  • Embedded data models

  • Fiori apps

  • Integration with finance and logistics

  • Local add-ons for country-specific mandates

It is ideal for companies that run S/4HANA (on-premise, private cloud or public cloud) and want compliance deeply integrated into transactional flows.

What Is Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition?

DRC Cloud Edition is SAP’s standalone, cloud-native compliance platform built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

It is designed to:

  • Support global e-invoicing mandates

  • Manage content-rich regulatory reporting

  • Centralize compliance across multiple ERP systems

  • Provide API-based connections to government platforms

  • Deliver continuous updates through the cloud

Unlike DRC embedded in S/4HANA, the Cloud Edition does not depend on the ERP release cycle, allowing SAP to push compliance updates faster and support new regulations more rapidly.

Key Differentiators: DRC vs. DRC Cloud Edition

Below are the main areas where the Cloud Edition differentiates itself from the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA.

1. Deployment Architecture

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
LocationRuns inside SAP S/4HANARuns outside ERP, on SAP BTP
DependenciesTied to ERP version & upgradesIndependent of ERP release cycle
UpdatesDelivered with S/4HANA feature packsContinuous cloud updates

Benefit: Faster adoption of new regulatory requirements with minimal impact on the ERP.

2. Multi-ERP and Non-SAP Integration

Aspect DRC DRC Cloud Edition
Supported systemsPrimarily SAP S/4HANAMulti-ERP, multi-system, including non-SAP
ConsolidationUsually per ERP instanceCentralized compliance hub

Benefit: Ideal for companies with multiple ERPs, global rollouts, or hybrid landscapes.

3. Scalability and Global Coverage

  • DRC Cloud Edition can scale more easily across countries.

  • SAP delivers regulatory content globally through cloud content packages.

  • Government API connectivity is managed centrally.

Benefit: Enterprises expand into new jurisdictions without large ERP projects.

4. Government Integrations and Connectivity

DRC Cloud Edition offers:

  • Managed API gateways to tax authorities

  • Continuous monitoring of government system changes

  • Central message tracking across countries

Benefit: Reduces IT workload and ensures higher resilience for e-invoicing and e-reporting.

5. Innovation, AI and Extensibility

Because it sits on SAP BTP, DRC Cloud Edition can leverage:

  • AI-driven anomaly detection

  • Intelligent validation of documents

  • Faster extensibility via low-code tools

  • Cloud automation services

Benefit: More innovation potential compared to the ERP-embedded DRC.

6. Upgrade Effort and Maintenance

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
Customer effortMust test with ERP upgradesMinimal customer testing
UpdatesPeriodicContinuous and automatic
MaintenanceShared between ERP team and tax complianceFully handled in the cloud

Benefit: Lower TCO and faster compliance readiness.

When to Choose Each Solution?

Choose DRC (Embedded in S/4HANA) if:

  • You want compliance tightly integrated into transactional finance and logistics.

  • You prefer a single solution inside S/4HANA.

  • You operate primarily in countries already supported within DRC.

Choose DRC Cloud Edition if:

  • You need global multi-country e-invoicing with fast deployment.

  • You operate multiple ERPs or hybrid landscapes.

  • You want rapid response to changing government mandates.

  • You need a future-proof cloud strategy with continuous innovation.

Conclusion

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition represents the evolution of digital tax compliance—faster, more scalable, and designed for a global, multi-system world.

While the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA remains a strong and deeply integrated option, the Cloud Edition expands capabilities with:

  • Cloud-native architecture

  • Faster regulatory updates

  • Centralized global management

  • Support for multiple ERPs

  • Continuous innovation via SAP BTP

Together, both solutions equip organizations to meet today’s regulatory environment and future-proof their compliance landscape.

entry.title: ¿Qué es IFRS 18? Explicación e Impacto para Clientes de SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
IFRS 18 redefine cómo se presentan resultados; en SAP S/4HANA implica reestructurar reportes, cuentas y subtotales para lograr transparencia, comparabilidad y cumplimiento global.

1. ¿Qué es IFRS 18?

IFRS 18 – Presentation and Disclosure in Financial Statements es la nueva norma emitida por IASB que sustituye a IAS 1.
Su objetivo es estandarizar y hacer más comparables los estados financieros entre empresas, mejorando la transparencia y consistencia en:

  • Presentación del estado de resultados

  • Clasificación de gastos

  • Subtotales obligatorios

  • Información por “gestión” (management approach)

  • Notas y revelaciones

Entrará en vigor a partir de 2027 (con adopción anticipada permitida).

2. ¿Qué cambia con IFRS 18? Principales novedades

A) Nuevas categorías obligatorias en el Estado de Resultados

IFRS 18 introduce tres nuevas categorías estandarizadas:

  1. Operating (Operativas)

  2. Investing (Inversiones)

  3. Financing (Financiamiento)

— además de requerir subtotales como Operating Profit.

B) Mayor claridad en gastos por función o por naturaleza

Las empresas deben elegir un solo enfoque principal y justificarlo.
Requiere revelaciones adicionales cuando los gastos se presentan por función.

C) Subtotales estandarizados obligatorios

Incluye métricas que antes eran voluntarias, ahora definidas bajo una guía uniforme.

D) Reglas más estrictas para “Management-defined Performance Measures (MPM)”

Cualquier KPI financiero que la administración use (como EBITDA ajustado, margen recurrente, etc.) debe:

  • Definirse formalmente

  • Explicarse

  • Conciliarse con IFRS

  • Divulgarse consistentemente

E) Cambios en notas y estructura narrativa

Nuevos requerimientos de presentación de información complementaria, con foco en consistencia.

3. Impacto para los clientes que utilizan SAP S/4HANA

1. Ajustes en el modelo de reporting financiero

Se deberán adaptar:

  • Estructuras del P&L

  • Versiones de reporte

  • Hierarquías financieras

  • Indicadores y subtotales

La nueva estructuración se resuelve especialmente con SAP Group Reporting.

2. Cambios en el modelo de cuentas y asignaciones

IFRS 18 exigirá revisar:

  • Clasificación de gastos operativos vs. no operativos

  • Determinación de categorías (operativa, inversión, financiamiento)

  • Cuentas contables y agrupaciones en FS Items

Esto puede requerir ajustes en:

  • Chart of Accounts (COA)

  • FS Item derivation

  • Profit center / Segment assignments

3. Reconfiguración de reportes y KPIs

IFRS 18 exige nuevos subtotales estandarizados como:

  • Operating Profit

  • Profit before Financing and Investing

  • Profit before Income Taxes

En SAP se habilitan mediante:

  • Fiori Analytical Apps

  • SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Group Reporting Data Collection (GRDC)

4. Impacto en empresas que usan CO-PA / Margin Analysis

Se necesitarán:

  • Nuevas derivaciones para categorías operativas/financieras

  • Alineación entre rentabilidad operativa interna y estado de resultados IFRS

Margin Analysis facilitará este alineamiento gracias al Universal Journal.

5. Mayor importancia de SAP Group Reporting

Group Reporting será crítico porque:

  • Permite mapear FS Items a categorías IFRS 18

  • Ajustar subtotales en consolidación

  • Alinear reportes individuales y consolidados

  • Gestionar KPI definidos por la administración (MPMs)

6. Impacto en divulgación y notas financieras

Con IFRS 18, empresas deberán generar notas más estructuradas y reconciliaciones nuevas.
SAP facilitará esto a través de:

  • GRDC (Group Reporting Data Collection)

  • Disclosure Management Tools

  • Plantillas estandarizadas para notas

7. Cambios en SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)

Para empresas que generen reportes locales a partir de estados IFRS, los cambios en P&L obligan a:

  • Revisar layouts

  • Ajustar reportes regulatorios

  • Sincronizar derivaciones financieras

4. ¿Qué deben hacer los clientes de SAP S/4HANA?

Acciones recomendadas:

1. Evaluación del modelo actual de P&L

Comparar la estructura existente vs. la requerida por IFRS 18.

2. Impact assessment técnico y funcional

Revisar COA, derivaciones, Fiori reports y Group Reporting.

3. Adecuación del reporting consolidado

Mapeo de FS Items → Nuevas categorías IFRS 18.

4. Ajustes en KPIs internos y MPMs

Alinear definiciones con la norma.

5. Actualización de procesos financieros

Cerrar brechas en notas, conciliaciones y subtotales.

entry.title: Re: the CDS of APP Monitor Value Chains
entry.content:
Hi @omega-ou 

Thank you for your question.

In public cloud you cannot use the monitor value chain app to build your report due to the lack of a CDS view that does that. The reason is SAP does not expose value chain engine tables or CDS views in public cloud. The app is based on internal reuse components that are not released for reporting, not visible in View Browser and not extendable through custom CDS.

To build your report, you must join the released analytical cubes yourself.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Mass migration of master data and fixed asset postings
entry.content:
Hello @SFerrand 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud does not provide any API or BAdI to migrate fixed asset master data or values. The best option is to stick to the migration cockpit and split the load into smaller batches.

I suggest you break the assets into batches of 20-50k assets per run. Then split your postings into multiple files.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @DianaRoesner 

Honestly, I came away very disappointed with the certification process. It makes me wonder if SAP has ever properly tested the UI.

I had read about the problems others faced — especially with submitting answers — and I tried the BDC certificate hoping those issues wouldn’t happen again. But the trouble started right away.

After accepting the agreement, I had to set up my camera and microphone. I did that, but the “Start” button stayed disabled, saying the camera wasn’t set. Refreshing didn’t help. Strangely, I could still click “Start,” but then I got a shocking error message.

I tried clicking “Restart,” just like it said, but that didn’t fix anything. The same error message popped up again.

I tried “Contact Us,” but instead of SAP support, I landed on a page from yoodli.ai. It just said “How can we help you?” — with no input box at all.  ????!!!!

On their website, the chat told me: “Send us a message, we’ll be back online tomorrow.”   !!!!!!!!

What made it worse was that the exam timer kept ticking down from two hours, even though I couldn’t access the exam at all. It was incredibly frustrating — just sitting there watching the clock run out on something I couldn’t even start. And then, after two hours, the system simply said “Time’s up,” and counted the attempt as failed.

So my questions are:

  • Was this UI ever properly tested before being rolled out?
  • Why hand over such an important exam process to a third-party company?
  • Shouldn’t certification exams be held on working days, when support is available, instead of weekends? Because if not, then the whole idea of ‘anywhere, anytime’ doesn’t make sense anymore.
  • And most importantly: how do I get back my attempt count for a test that never even began?

I’ve already opened a support case with the Learning Support Team, and I really hope they answer quickly — even on the weekend —

entry.title: Re: Clicking “Components Missing” in Manage Production Or...
entry.content:
Good day @Aght 

Thank you for your question.

  1. Answer to question 1: This often happens if target app could not be found and it therefore returns you to the homepage. Potentially the app is not assigned to your business role.
  2. Answer to question 2: Yes, they are.
  3. Answer to question 3: You need either one of the following roles: SAP_BR_PRODN_PLNR which ensures you have the planner rights in production or SAP_BR_PRODN_SUPERVISOR which gives you the supervisor permission.
  4. Answer to question 4: Yes, it is common in the demo tenants. This is because, in the demo tenants the full catalog are not deployed. Some objects are missing; the missing Parts app and some cross-navigation mappings are either missing or incomplete. As a result, when you click the link, you are routed back to the Launchpad.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Monitor External Requirements – “Too many data record...
entry.content:
Good day @Aght 

Thank you for your question.

To answer your first question, yes it is if your filter function does not cover the required fields.

The system seems to be working as designed. If you miss any critical selection parameter, the backend reads the full MRP dataset and triggers too many records and thereby returns no results. Which then shows no data.

First, I suggest you also filter the Requirement Evaluation Period to limit the search the system carries out. If something is available, the system should generate data.

Alternatively, it could also mean you have no external requirement open for the chosen plants and products. and therefore, no data is generated. I ran the test and the system also provided no data.

What I also did is to run a check on the Monitor Material Coverage APP. As you can see below, the system produced some data showing there are shortages. I suggest you check in this app using the same materials on your screenshot to evaluate if you have some shortages. If you did not find any, then the Alert.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Hide company code by default
entry.content:
Good day @TobiasVoigt 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Configuring Business Roles, Assigning Business Roles to a User, Best Practices for Business Roles, How to Create a Business Role from a Template, Restricting Access Roles, Manage Consolidation Hierarchies

To summarise, the public cloud provides the restriction request through business role restrictions and not through structural configuration. The simplest clean-core way to do what you are intending, is to create one dedicated role that explicitly allows this company code, while all other roles remain without access. Which then means, only users with this special role will see the company code in apps, analytics and value helps. This helps you avoid role duplication.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Copy Text from Sevrice Order to Billing Document
entry.content:
Good day @simon_all4cloud41 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud does not offer the possibility to transfer service order or service confirmation texts directly into the Billing Document text tabs. You can only do that for SD documents.

Considering the public cloud principle restricts some functionalities, you can only achieve your requirements without custom fields by including the text in the billing output PDF and enabling a service confirmation text through output parameter determination and then map it into the billing form.

However, if your business requirement is to store the text inside the Billing Document itself, you can achieve it only through custom field and custom logic.

Have a look at the following references.

Service Processing Using a Service Order, Service Order Processing,  Service Order - Confirm Processing, Billing Document, Output Determination in the Billing Document

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Event Driven SAP CAP on Kyma with Agentic AI and UI Auto Refresh
entry.content:
Introduction:
This prototype demonstrates how a simple CAP application can evolve into an event-driven architecture enriched with autonomous agentic AI. The objective was to show how CAP can react to external events in real time, refresh the UI automatically, and trigger an AI workflow that identifies duplicate citizens without any user action. The solution combines Kyma, SAP CAP, SAP HANA Cloud DB, SAP Integration Suite, a Python agent/Open AI, all running together.

Demo:

End-to-End Flow:
This application is built around a simple idea: when a citizen is created in the system, everything should react automatically.

The process starts in SAP Integration Suite. This is the continuation of the last Blog Post . The iFlow inserts the new citizen into HANA Cloud and then calls CAP’s notify endpoint with a simple JSON payload. This notify call is the explicit trigger, because CAP does not detect database changes on its own. Once CAP receives the notification, it broadcasts the event through its citizen stream endpoint using Server-Sent Events.

The UI and the Python agent are both listening to this stream. When they receive the event, each reacts independently. The UI refreshes its Fiori Elements binding and displays the new record. The agent retrieves the citizen through CAP OData, performs duplicate detection, prompts Open AI, and writes its suggestions back through CAP. CAP exposes the suggestions via virtual enrichment fields so that the UI automatically displays AI insights during the next read.

 

iFlow Changes:

Code:

GitHub: User - shahidla. Repository - citizen-master-cap-docker

Agentic AI:
The agent is packaged as a Python container running in Kyma. It listens continuously to the citizen stream. When it receives a CitizenCreated event it reads the citizen through OData, prompts Open AI with a structured tool-based instruction set and follows the returned JSON. Open AI selects the next actions such as fetching the citizen again, running a duplicate search or writing the final suggestion.

To make the AI transparent, a thinking log table records each step in the agent run including search inputs, candidate lists, scores and final reasoning. Users can view not only the AI result but also how the agent reached that conclusion. This makes the system trustworthy and audit friendly rather than a black box.

Execution results:

AI Agent Thinking Logs:

Conclusion:
This prototype shows that a CAP application can be extended into a fully event driven and agentic AI and can all run together inside Kyma without additional infrastructure The result is a responsive and intelligent application that reacts to new information immediately and explains every decision it makes.

Disclaimer:
This prototype intended for learning and demonstration. It is not production grade and does not include full durability. AI reasoning results should be validated and not used for decisions without proper governance. A real solution would require reviewing security, performance, and data privacy aspects. Terminology may have been used freely as part of experimentation.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model: What’s New as of 2025-12-01?
entry.content:
Greetings, SAP Community! 

The SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Universal Model continues to advance, and in this blogpost, I will outline the latest features and enhancements designed to further improve efficiency, transparency, and agility in business modeling and performance analysis. 

Model 

Manage Transfer Structure new type Reverse Transfer Structure 

Transfer Structure is a Function that helps reshaping or enriching your data based on the rules you set up. Think of each rule as a simple “if this happens, then do that” instruction. The “if” part tells SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model when a rule should apply—basically which rows to look at. The “then” part tells SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model what to change in those rows, like filling in certain fields or replacing values. If the data doesn’t meet the conditions in your rule, SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model just leaves it alone and passes it through untouched.  

The Transfer Structure function now has two (2) Types.    

  

With the new Reverse Transfer Structure type, it takes data that is spread across multiple columns and transforms it into rows. This is often called “unpivoting” the data. It’s helpful when you need to turn wide tables into a long, tidy format that’s easier to analyze or use in calculations.  

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model  Transfer Structure > Reverse Transfer Structure   

Data Screen Improvements: Global Renaming and Visibility Control  

Previously, a feature in the Data screen was introduced wherein you can rename the field description. When you changed a field name, it changed only in Data screen specific layout where the renaming of field was done. Now with the “Store Globally in Environment” option enabled, any field change which includes renaming, is automatically applied across all layouts within the same environment.  

If a field in the Data Screen is renamed with the “Store Globally in Environment” option checked in the Edit Column dialog (opened by choosing Edit (pencil) icon), the new name is applied globally in all layouts of the environment. Renaming of such fields will also be applied globally, and the following message will be displayed: “Field was renamed globally. Next renaming also will be applied globally.”. 

Apart from the field renaming enhancements in Data Screen, another enhancement has been done in Data screen wherein if the Field has the Control Type Hidden in the function configuration (Model Entity), the field will not be displayed in any Data screen layouts (Standard and Customized). It will no longer available in the Columns panel or Reports Show Elements and will also be excluded from exports. It will ensure consistent behavior and alignment with hidden field logic across all layouts. 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model Data Screen 

Process 

Transport Support for Manage Data Locks, Manage Data Privilege and Manage Layouts  

A new feature has been implemented in which Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts created for AddOn environment are now transportable wherein these will be included upon environment export when marked for transport, even if they refer to a function owned by a protected environment. Once exported, they can be moved to the target tenant through environment import. This also applies to regular/unprotected environments as well.  

Important points to note: 

  • During environment export, Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts will be excluded if it refers to a function or activity function (e.g. activity within runtime environment but assigned activity function from another runtime environment) from a different environment. There will be a warning message that will be prompted upon export action and logged in Event Logs. 
  • During environment import, Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts with inconsistent values (e.g. referring to a non-existing function or activity) will prompt an error message that a function or activity is missing in the target tenant.  
  • During AddOn environment import, the existence of the external function will be validated. If the function is not found in the target tenant, it will be removed from the corresponding Data Locks and Data Privileges. 

How does it work? 

For the following scenario, Tenant 01 will be the source tenant and Tenant 02 will be the target tenant. 

Source Tenant 01 - New field “Transport Data Privilege” checkbox is displayed in Data Privilege object page which can be marked as enabled and unmarked as disabled. This applies to Data Locks as well.  

Source Tenant 01 - Upon save of Data Privilege, it will show as “Yes” when Transport Data Privilege checkbox is marked while it will show as “-“ when unmarked. This applies to Data Locks as well.  

When enabled, transportable Data Privileges and Data Locks will be included in the exported environment container.  

 

Target Tenant 02 - Upon environment import and activation, the transportable Data Privilege and Data Locks has been moved to the target tenant. 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model Manage Layouts, Manage Data Privileges, and Manage Data Locks 

Manage Process and Manage Activities: Updating Activity Run Status after Process reset  

 A new behavior has been implemented that the Run Status will be reset together with State of a dependent Activity. Run Status will change from its initial value after execution (which can be “OK”, “Warning”, or “Error”) to its default value “No Run” upon Process reset.   

The State of a dependent Activity will still have the same behavior wherein its initial value (which can be “Active”, “Confirmed”, or “Rejected”) will be changed to its default value “Inactive” once Process is reset. This behavior applies as well to Process and Activity elements in Report Screen.  

The purpose of this change is to avoid misleading information when determining an Activity whether the task is completed or not.   

 Activity after Run is performed  

  

 Process resetting  

Activity after Process reset is performed  

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model  Manage Processes - Reset  

Thank you for taking the time to read this update. 

We invite you to explore the newest enhancements in the SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model, and we encourage you to follow our ongoing “What’s New” series. For previous updates, feel free to browse the PaPMCloudUMWhatsNew tag.

entry.title: Re: How to populated the VAT registration number for Busi...
entry.content:
Hi Emal,

In ECC, the tax numbers are stored in Tax number 1, 2,3,4,5 and VAT registration field which are separate fields on screen of XK01 and in table KNA1. However In S4 HANA, we have 1 tab for Tax Numbers which you have highlighted. In expects a category and tax number. Category is nothing but a combination of "Country cod and N".  N is derived based on where the tax is stored in ECC. If customer is from Italy and tax is stored in Tax number 1 in ECC then N = 1 and tax category in S4 HANA is IT1. Similarly Tax number 2 has value then IT2, Tax number 3 = IT3, Tax Number4 = IT4, Tax Number 5 = IT5 and VAT in ECC is 0 meaning tax category will always be IT0.

So in your case it would be category 0 for VAT number.

Customer Tax category     Tax Number

12345        DE0                     DE0000***

Please reward if you find this answer helpful. Also confirm if this helps

entry.title: Mastering GitOps with Argo CD: A Complete Guide to Declarative Kubernetes Deployments
entry.content:
Introduction

In the world of cloud-native engineering, agility and reliability often clash. Developers need speed; operators need control. Traditional CI/CD pipelines, though effective, rely heavily on manual approvals, ad-hoc scripting, and push-based workflows — all prone to configuration drift and human error.

GitOps changes the game by using Git as the single source of truth for both infrastructure and application configurations. With Argo CD, a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery controller, you can automate deployments, enforce configuration consistency, and self-heal your clusters — all through declarative manifests stored in Git.

This article provides an end-to-end, production-ready walkthrough of how to design, deploy, and operate Kubernetes workloads using Argo CD and GitOps principles — including advanced features such as multi-environment automation, Helm integration, sync policies, and best practices for scale.

What Is GitOps?

GitOps is a modern methodology for managing and operating cloud-native infrastructure and applications using Git as the single source of truth. It shifts the deployment paradigm from manual, imperative commands (like kubectl apply) to a declarative, automated workflow, where the desired state of your system is stored and versioned in Git.

Key principles of GitOps include:

1. Git as the Source of Truth

  • All infrastructure and application configurations are defined declaratively in Git.
  • Git commits represent the desired system state, enabling versioning, traceability, and auditability.

2. Pull-Based Automation

  • A GitOps operator continuously monitors Git for changes and reconciles the live system with the desired state.
  • Any drift between Git and the running environment is detected and corrected automatically.

3. Automated Rollbacks and Auditing

  • Since every change is a Git commit, rolling back to a previous state is as simple as reverting a commit.
  • All actions are auditable, providing a clear history of changes and deployments.

In essence: With GitOps, you declare what you want, commit it to Git, and let automation ensure that your cluster matches that desired state — reliably, securely, and consistently.

It combines the benefits of version control, CI/CD, and automation into a single, streamlined approach for managing modern cloud-native applications.

Why Choose Argo CD?

Argo CD is a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery tool that fully implements GitOps principles, making it an ideal choice for teams seeking automation, reliability, and scalability. Here’s why Argo CD stands out:

1. Continuous Synchronization

  • Automatically monitors Git repositories and synchronizes changes to Kubernetes clusters.
  • Ensures the live state always matches the desired state defined in Git.

2. Real-Time Drift Detection and Self-Healing

  • Detects any manual changes or configuration drift in the cluster.
  • Automatically corrects deviations to maintain consistency.

3. Multi-Cluster and Multi-Environment Support

  • Manage deployments across multiple clusters and environments from a single Argo CD instance.
  • Supports environment overlays for dev, staging, and production setups.

4. Application Visualization and Health Monitoring

  • Provides a UI and CLI to visualize application status, dependencies, and health.
  • Supports monitoring health states like Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, or Suspended.

5. Support for Multiple Deployment Tools

  • Deploy raw YAML, Helm charts, Kustomize overlays, or Jsonnet configurations.
  • Flexible enough to handle simple apps or complex, multi-service systems.

6. Secure and Role-Based Access

  • Built-in RBAC for controlling access to applications, clusters, and repositories.
  • Ensures secure operations in collaborative, multi-team environments.

In short: Argo CD transforms Git commits into the live state of your Kubernetes clusters — consistently, automatically, and safely — making it a trusted GitOps engine for modern cloud-native deployments.

Step 1: Setting Up Argo CD

Let’s deploy Argo CD in a Kubernetes cluster.

Prerequisites

  • A Kubernetes cluster (Minikube, Kind, AKS, EKS, or GKE)
  • kubectl installed and configured
  • A GitHub or GitLab repository for your manifests

Installing Commands

kubectl create namespace argocd
kubectl apply -n argocd \
  -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/argoproj/argo-cd/stable/manifests/install.yaml

Once deployed, Argo CD runs several components:

  • argocd-server – exposes the UI, API, and CLI
  • argocd-repo-server – interacts with Git repositories
  • argocd-application-controller – reconciles application states
  • argocd-dex-server – handles authentication
  • argocd-redis – caching and internal coordination

Accessing the UI

kubectl port-forward svc/argocd-server -n argocd 8080:443

Then open https://localhost:8080.

Retrieve the admin password:

kubectl -n argocd get secret argocd-initial-admin-secret \
  -o jsonpath="{.data.password}" | base64 -d

 

Step 2: Connecting a Git Repository

In the Argo CD UI:
Settings → Repositories → Connect Repo → Add Git URL + Credentials.

Alternatively, via CLI:

argocd repo add https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git \
  --username <user> --password <token>

Argo CD now watches this repository and continuously scans it for configuration changes.

Step 3: Creating and Deploying Applications

Applications are the core Argo CD resources. They define what to deploy, where, and how.

Sample Application Definition

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
metadata:
  name: nginx-demo
  namespace: argocd
spec:
  project: default
  source:
    repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git
    path: apps/nginx
    targetRevision: main
  destination:
    server: https://kubernetes.default.svc
    namespace: demo
  syncPolicy:
    automated:
      prune: true
      selfHeal: true
    syncOptions:
      - CreateNamespace=true

Apply this:

kubectl apply -f nginx-application.yaml

Argo CD fetches the manifests, applies them to the cluster, and keeps them in sync with Git automatically.

 

Step 4: Understanding Deployment Strategies

Argo CD supports multiple deployment approaches:

1. Plain YAML

Store raw manifests under version control — simplest setup but less flexible.

2. Helm Charts

Argo CD can deploy Helm charts directly without helm CLI:

source:
  repoURL: https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami
  chart: nginx
  targetRevision: 13.2.9
  helm:
    values: |
      replicaCount: 3
      service:
        type: ClusterIP

3. Kustomize Overlays

Perfect for multi-environment management:

my-app/
├── base/
│   ├── deployment.yaml
│   ├── service.yaml
│   └── kustomization.yaml
├── overlays/
│   ├── dev/
│   │   └── kustomization.yaml
│   └── prod/
│       └── kustomization.yaml

4. App-of-Apps Pattern

Used to manage complex systems:

source:
  repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/environment-configs.git
  path: environments/dev

Step 5: Configuration and Synchronization

Sync Policies

Argo CD supports both manual and automated synchronization.

  • Manual Mode: Operators review and trigger syncs manually.
  • Automated Mode: Argo CD applies changes as soon as they are committed to Git.

Example:

syncPolicy:
  automated:
    prune: true
    selfHeal: true
  • Prune removes obsolete resources that no longer exist in Git.
  • SelfHeal ensures that any manual cluster change is automatically reverted.

Sync Options

Argo CD provides advanced sync behaviors:

syncOptions:
  - CreateNamespace=true
  - ApplyOutOfSyncOnly=true
  - PrunePropagationPolicy=foreground

Hooks and Lifecycle Management

You can use Argo CD Resource Hooks to run pre- and post-deployment tasks like database migrations or config validation.

Example:

metadata:
  annotations:
    argocd.argoproj.io/hook: PreSync

Step 6: Observability and Health Monitoring

Argo CD continuously monitors application health using Kubernetes object statuses.

  • Health states: Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, Suspended
  • You can visualize these in the Argo CD UI tree view.

For deeper insights:

  • Metrics: Argo CD exposes Prometheus metrics at /metrics.
  • Dashboards: Integrate with Grafana to visualize sync frequency, drift count, and app health.
  • Notifications: Use Argo CD Notifications for Slack, Teams, or email alerts.

Example config:

triggers:
  - name: on-sync-failure
    condition: app.status.sync.status == 'OutOfSync'
    template: sync-failure

Step 7: Real-World Deployment Workflow

Here’s a simplified GitOps deployment lifecycle using Argo CD:

  1. Developer updates the manifest or Helm values → commits to Git.
  2. CI validates YAML syntax and performs static checks.
  3. Commit is merged to the main branch.
  4. Argo CD detects the commit, fetches the new configuration, and starts reconciliation.
  5. Application is deployed to the cluster.
  6. If any manual drift occurs, Argo CD flags “OutOfSync” and reverts automatically.
  7. Rollback is as easy as git revert <commit-hash>.

This process guarantees full traceability, automatic rollback, and no manual cluster changes.

Summary: Argo CD as the GitOps Engine

Argo CD brings automation, reliability, and control to Kubernetes deployments through GitOps. It replaces manual, error-prone processes with a declarative, Git-driven model where every change is versioned, traceable, and automatically synchronized to clusters. As environments scale across microservices and multiple clusters, Argo CD ensures consistency, eliminates drift, and enables faster, safer releases. Ultimately, it transforms Git into the operational control plane and provides a predictable, self-healing, and highly observable deployment workflow — allowing teams to move quickly without compromising stability.

You define your desired state once, commit to Git, and Argo CD ensures your clusters reflect it — continuously and automatically.

This declarative model brings:

  • Auditability: every change is a commit
  • Reliability: drift is self-corrected
  • Scalability: consistent rollout across clusters
  • Security: code-based governance over live clusters

Conclusion

Argo CD is more than a deployment tool — it is the operational engine that modernizes how organizations manage Kubernetes at scale. By embracing GitOps, teams shift from fragile, manual, push-based deployments to a fully automated, audit-ready, and self-healing delivery model. Every environment becomes predictable, every rollout becomes traceable, and every configuration becomes reproducible.

As applications grow into distributed microservices and clusters expand across regions or clouds, Argo CD provides the consistency and governance required to keep everything in sync. Its declarative, pull-based architecture eliminates configuration drift, while features like automated sync, app-of-apps orchestration, Helm/Kustomize support, and environment overlays allow teams to design enterprise-grade delivery pipelines with confidence.

In essence, Argo CD turns Git into a control plane for your entire Kubernetes footprint. It bridges the gap between developers and operators by delivering a unified, reliable, and observable deployment workflow.

Adopting GitOps with Argo CD is not just a tooling decision — it is an engineering culture upgrade. It empowers teams to deploy faster, recover instantly, collaborate better, and operate with clarity at every stage of the software lifecycle.

In a world where speed and stability are equally critical, Argo CD ensures you never have to choose between the two.

entry.title: Re: The destination set for ur participant ID does not ma...
entry.content:
Root cause:

  • The participant ID you are using as the sender in eCockpit is linked to a destination that does not correspond to the system from which you are submitting the document.
  • This often happens when:
    • The destination in SAP BTP is incorrectly configured.
    • The participant ID mapping in the Master Data Management app or Peppol Exchange Service is missing or incorrect.
    • The wrong system alias or destination name is assigned in the eDocument Cockpit configuration

Solution

The destination set for your participant ID does not match the system you are trying to submit the electronic document from” in SAP eDocument Cockpit (eCockpit) usually occurs due to a mismatch between the participant ID configuration and the destination system settings in SAP BTP.

1. Verify Participant ID Setup

  • Go to SAP Document and Reporting Compliance → Master Data Management App.
  • Check that the participant ID is registered and linked to the correct system.
  • If using Peppol or similar network, ensure the participant ID is active for sending (and optionally receiving) documents

2. Check Destination in SAP BTP Cockpit

  • Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit.
  • Navigate to Connectivity → Destinations.
  • Confirm:
    • The destination name matches what is configured in eCockpit.
    • The URL/host points to the correct system (S/4HANA or middleware).
    • Authentication settings are correct.
  • If needed, edit and save the destination

3. Validate Additional Parameters

  • In the destination configuration, check Additional Properties:
    • sap-client (client number)
    • systemAlias or similar identifiers
  • These must match the system you are submitting from.

4. Update eCockpit Settings

  • In EDOC_COCKPIT or Manage Electronic Documents (Fiori):
    • Ensure the communication arrangement (e.g., SAP_COM_0521) is linked to the correct destination.
    • If using Integration Suite, verify the outbound service destination is correct.

5. Clear and Retry

  • After correcting configuration:
    • Clear the error in eCockpit.
    • Resubmit the document

entry.title: Re: how to upgrade SAP BTP trial account to free tier acc...
entry.content:
Hi jerlin_d,

Furthermore, I want to emphasize that 'Free Tier' is not an account type, but a "set of free services that can be used within an enterprise account", for details see below reference [1].
There you could also find how to get an enterprise account, where 'Free Tier', set set of free services, can be use.

Your personal free trial is not an enterprise account, and even though you can use there many BTP Services for free, not all of the 'Free Tier' is currently offered in personal trial accounts, like SAP AI Core.

Hope that helps.
Best regards, Jens

[1] https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/getting-global-account?version=Cloud

entry.title: 借助 Data Source Extension 将更重要的业务信息字段显示在 Fiori App 中
entry.content:
技术简介

Data Source Extension / 数据源扩展 / 資料來源延伸 是 SAP ERP 云中一项重要的关键用户可扩展性应用。其基本技术原理为，基于某一项系统标准预制的“Business Context / 业务上下文 / 業務內容”，关键用户将系统标准提供的更多数据字段或自定义字段添加其中，进而通过“Adapt UI / UI 调整模式 / 調整使用者介面”使这些字段在对应的 Fiori App 中显示出来。

应用场景

S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 中各 Fiori App 的标准设计参考了更广泛的客户与行业应用诉求。若您的企业在个性化管理的诉求中，业务用户关注的字段并未在 SAP 标准设计中得以呈现，作为系统实施方或关键用户，您即可通过本文介绍的技术手段将这些字段呈现到 Fiori App 中。

实例讲解

业务背景

当采购员使用 Post Goods Movement / 过账货物移动 / 過帳物料異動（MIGO）App 进行收货时，可以在“Supplier Batch / 供应商批次 / 供應商批次”字段中填入供应商方的货品批次号。该字段会被 SAP ERP 云系统记录，并可被用于后续的溯源需求。在 Web GUI App MIGO 中回看货物移动凭证时，可以在“Batch / 批次”页签中，点击“Classification / 分类 / 分類”按钮，在弹窗中的“Basic Data 1 / 基本数据 / 基本資料”页签中查看到 Supplier Batch 信息。

但若用户使用新的 Fiori App Material Documents Overview / 物料凭证概览 / 物料文件概觀（F1077）查看已创建的货物移动凭证，标准 UI 中却无法找到此 Supplier Batch 的信息。

解决方案

实施方或具有相关权限的关键用户可以在配置实施环境（三系统架构 D/100，或两系统架构 Q/100）中，按以下步骤完成相关设定，并传输至生产环境供终端用户使用。

步骤 1：在 Custom Fields / 自定义字段 / 自訂欄位 App 中，为数据源“Material Document Items (Display) / 物料凭证项目（显示）/ 物料文件項目〈顯示〉”增加 Supplier Batch 字段。

1) 打开 Custom Fields App，点击页签“Data Source Extensions / 数据源扩展 / 資料來源延伸”。点击右侧按钮 + ，创建一个新的 Data Source Extension。

  • Data Source / 数据源 / 資料來源：选择编码为 MMIM_MATDOC_OV_SRV 的数据源。
  • Description / 描述 / 說明：填写该增强的应用场景说明，如“Supplier Batch” 。
  • Extension ID / 扩展标识 / 延伸 ID：系统会依据您填写的 Description 自动生成一个关键用户增强编码，您也可以手动调整。

2) 填写完信息后，点击“Create / 创建 / 建立”，系统会导览至该增强的编辑页面。点击页签“Field Selection / 字段选择 / 欄位選取”。从左侧的“Available Fields / 可用字段 / 可用欄位”中依次展开“Find Material Document Items / 查找物料凭证项目 / 尋找物料文件項目” > “Batch Information / 批次信息 / 批次資訊”。接着从列表中勾选字段 Supplier Batch，您会看到选中的字段被添加到了右侧的“Selected Fields / 所选字段 / 所選欄位”清单中。您可以调整“Field Name / 字段名称 / 欄位名稱”，或采用系统默认设定的字段名。确认无误后，点击右下角的按钮“Publish / 发布 / 發佈” 以部署该增强。

请注意，这一步骤并未在系统数据库的物理表中新增自定义字段，只是将数据源中的字段补充在了前端调用的接口中。

步骤2：在 Material Documents Overview App 的凭证显示页面中，将数据源中补充的 Supplier Batch 字段显示出来。

1) 打开 Material Documents Overview App，从结果清单中点击打开任一凭证的详情页面。

2) 停留在该页面中，点击右上角的人形按钮，再点击“Adapt UI / UI 调整模式 / 調整使用者介面”选项进入该程序页面的 UI 调整模式。

3) 单击页面中您想要展示 Supplier Batch 的区块，例如 Document Notes，在弹窗中点击“Add: Field / 添加：字段 / 新增：欄位”。

4) 在弹窗中，搜索 Supplier Batch，您将能看到在前序步骤中新增的数据源字段 Supplier Batch。选中该字段，并点击“OK / 确定 / 確定”。您将看到该字段成功地显示在了该 App 页面上。您还可以拖拽该字段以调整其显示的位置。

5) 对于该 App 页面的修改，您可以点击右上角的磁盘图标进行保存。若您确认已完成调整，需要点击左上角的激活按钮，输入一个增强版本说明后，点击“Confirm / 确认 / 確認”。最后点击左上角的发布按钮，系统将开始在后台为您发布这一变更，使当前系统环境下所有用户均可看到这一变更。

6) 最后，点击右上角的 X 按钮，退出该程序页面的 UI 调整模式。到此，您就完成了所有的调整设定，实现了该业务需求。

总结

在 SaaS 软件服务中，除了依托标准产品的创新交付获取新的业务功能外，S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 也提供了例如 Data Source Extension 这样简捷、无代码的可扩展性，供关键用户或实施方快速地调整 Fiori App 的页面信息字段与布局呈现。

若针对您的业务场景所需的数据源，系统尚未提供目标业务上下文或源字段供个性化调整，您可以将相关诉求提至 SAP Customer Influence Portal。SAP 产品开发团队将依据广大的客户群体反馈，持续迭代创新。

entry.title: Re: Destinations Not Available in Automations
entry.content:
Make sure:

  1. The destination is also created in your BTP subaccount (not only in SAP Build Control Tower):

    • Go to BTP Cockpit → Subaccount → Connectivity → Destinations.

    • Confirm an equivalent destination exists there with:

       *Type = HTTP or Type = OAuth2... (supported types),

      • Proxy Type typically Internet or OnPremise as needed,

      • Authentication is one of the supported ones.

  2. In Control Tower → Destinations you might have created a “Build-only” destination which:

    • Is visible to Action Projects,

    • But not automatically to Automations.

If it exists only in Control Tower and not in BTP, add it also in BTP.

 

  • Check which subaccount / region your Automation project belongs to.

  • Check if the destination in the BTP cockpit exists in that same subaccount.

entry.title: Non‑PO Invoices: When to Use Them and When Not
entry.content:
Invoices submitted without a reference to a purchase order or a contract are common in many organizations. For their lack of reference, they are referred as non-PO Invoices in the invoice processing systems across the AP scope.

Non‑PO invoices solve real problems but also introduce risks. In this short guide I'm trying to explain how often they are used, when they make sense, what risks they represent, and practical actions to be taken by procurement leaders.

How much they’re used

Typical usage of non-PO invoices by organizations lies in 5–30% interval of invoice volume and 5–25% of AP spend. This can differ per industry segments, but higher ratios exceeding 30% may be indicators of slow PO processes, high services spend, many small vendors, or immature procurement systems. For organizations it points to opportunities for improvements in their efficiency and compliance targets.

When non‑PO invoices make sense

There are cases, where non-PO invoices are unavoidable and include number of scenarios that can be handled without loosing control:

  • Emergency or safety‑critical purchases where creating a PO would cause unwanted delays
  • Professional services billed on milestones, time & materials, or when scope/price is agreed after work begins
    (unless they are covered by contracts to which the invoices could be referring to)
  • Suppliers that cannot accept POs (small/legacy suppliers in challenging regions)
  • Very low‑value transactions where PO overhead exceeds benefit
  • Highly exceptional cases, when PO cannot be created, e.g. system outages, transitions, etc.

When non‑PO invoices are NOT a good practice

Sometimes organizations keep their "long term" legacy practices, because "it is so comfortable to do it our time-proven way". Many opportunities can be missed, more manual effort in the invoice matching activities is required, and organizations tend to run in circles, unable to unlock the trap.

Try to avoid the following (or similar) areas, where non-PO invoices are part of the picture:  

  • Repeat purchases from the same supplier that should be on contract or catalog
  • High‑value or strategic spend where PO terms protect pricing, delivery and liability
  • Categories with clear opportunities for consolidation or volume discounts
  • Environments with known fraud or duplicate payment risk and weak AP controls

When there is an overlay between the existing structured buying channels (catalog/contract spend), or guarding commercial terms (payment/delivery/liability), non-PO invoices can be easily replaced. This will deliver efficiency improvements. 

Pros and cons

Decision makers in the procurement organizations might be aware of the positive and negative aspects of the non-PO invoice practice in their purchasing processes. Here is the overview:

  •  Pros
    • Speed and flexibility for urgent or complex purchases
    • Preserves supplier relationships when suppliers won’t accept POs
    • Simpler for T&M or milestone invoicing for services (if tools for contract compliance/services spend are unavailable)
  • Cons
    • Higher maverick spend, weak spend control
    • Low visibility into budget, contracts and supplier performance
    • Higher AP processing costs and more invoice exceptions
    • Increased risk of fraud or duplicate payments
    • Slower month‑end reconciliation and weaker sourcing discipline

Practical policy decisions and actions

  1. Define acceptable exceptions
    • Publish a short list of allowed cases (emergency, validated supplier, low‑value threshold, services)
    • require a business justification field on every non‑PO invoice

  2. Set clear thresholds & approval matrix
    • Use amount thresholds tied to approval levels
      (e.g., Dept Manager for <500; Directorfor<5k; Procurement+Finance for larger amounts)
  3. Automate non‑PO workflows
    • Force mandatory fields (exception reason, GL code, cost center)
    • Route approvals automatically, and capture justification in the AR/AP system

  4. Monitor & report monthly
    • Track count and value of non‑PO invoices, repeat suppliers, time‑to‑approval, and % of total AP spend
    • Create alerts for repeat non‑PO suppliers

  5. Convert repeat non‑PO spend
    • Onboard frequent non‑PO suppliers to catalogs, negotiated contracts or a managed marketplace (SpotBuy) within 60–90 days

  6. Strengthen supplier onboarding
    • Ensure vendors used for non‑PO invoices have basic validations (tax forms, bank details, insurance) before payments over a threshold

  7. Balance convenience with control
    • Offer low‑friction PO alternatives (catalogs, SpotBuy, pre‑approved templates) to reduce the need of non‑PO invoices

  8. Audit & continuous improvement
    • Periodically audit samples of non‑PO invoices for compliance, fraud indicators and opportunities to source differently

Quick target benchmarks 

How do you know, where you stand and whether you are successful in achieving your targets? You might want to use this simple guide of measurable process metrics to help you gain visibility of the non-PO invoicing process:

  • Healthy: non‑PO invoice volume <15% and non‑PO spend <10% of AP
  • Risky: non‑PO invoice volume 15–30% or non‑PO spend 10–25% — implement remediation plan
  • Alarm: non‑PO invoice volume >30% or non‑PO spend >25% — immediate controls, audit, and supplier enablement required

 

Final takeaway

Non‑PO invoices should be a controlled exception, not the norm. Make sure to limit their use with a clear policy, automate approvals and data capture, track them closely, and convert recurring non‑PO purchases into PO‑based channels where better savings, visibility and control can be delivered.

entry.title: Searchability of Custom Attributes in Process Manager
entry.content:
Hi everyone!

We have created some custom attributes for Dictionary entries in SAP Signavio Process Manager but we cannot use them to search these entries.

Is there a way to make these custom attributes searchable, so that searching by a custom attribute value would bring up the list of dictionary entries using it? 

Also, is there any other option for searchable tagging that we could use instead?

Any guidance is appreciated, thank you 🙂

entry.title: Re: Datasphere SQL: expected_unsigned_integer error on ti...
entry.content:
Perhaps you could create your own function to output a given value at a the length detemined by the parameter?

Copilot came up with this:

CREATE FUNCTION TruncateString (
    input NVARCHAR(5000),
    length INT
)
RETURNS NVARCHAR(5000)
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE result NVARCHAR(5000);

    -- If input is NULL, return NULL
    IF :input IS NULL THEN
        result := NULL;
    ELSE
        -- If length is less than 1, return empty string
        IF :length <= 0 THEN
            result := '';
        ELSE
            -- Use SUBSTRING to truncate
            result := SUBSTRING(:input, 1, :length);
        END IF;
    END IF;

    RETURN :result;
END;

entry.title: Where Is My Stuff? — Joule’s First Industry Release Brings AI-Driven Insight to Oil and Gas Upstream
entry.content:
The oil and gas domain has historically been one of the most stable but also conservative areas of enterprise architecture. Over multiple decades, SAP customers have evolved from custom ABAP solutions to standardized S/4HANA objects, Fiori applications, and integrated complex logistics planning and processes. While this has driven consistency and transactional efficiency, the core decision-making mechanisms in field logistics remained predominantly human-driven with, manual validation, and the experience of field and personnel.

SAP Field Logistics is a solution built on SAP S/4HANA. It is available on both S/4HANA private cloud and public cloud.  This solution enables customers leverage best in class industry practices to manage the logistics movement of their own- and third-party items between their supply and demand plants. 

We are happy to announce that in May 2025, we at SAP introduced a landmark innovation:

the very first Joule-enabled capability across all industries, delivered specifically within SAP Upstream Field Logistics.

This early release is subtle in scope but monumental in strategic significance. It marks the beginning of Field Logistics evolution from traditional business processes to a future where core FL operations become deeply AI-driven through Joule.

A Strategic First Step: Joule’s Inventory Insights for FL

The initial capability released in May focuses on a read-only non-stock inventory scenario, allowing users to retrieve consolidated product and equipment visibility through natural language and gives the latest milestone of its lifecycle to help to know where the equipment is located. Even though this first use case is intentionally controlled, it is designed as the foundation for a multi-release future where Joule will perform full field logistics (FL) transactions end-to-end.

SAP’s intention is clear:

Start small, prove value, ensure reliability, and then scale AI-driven operations across the entire upstream lifecycle.

This first release demonstrates Joule’s ability to:

  • Understand Field Logistics terminology in 50 different languages
  • Interpret users queries through Natural Language Processing and provide contextual answers instantly
  • Display list of products along with relevant information’s like plant, Purchase order, different quantities etc
  • Navigate to Manage logistics application from Joule to get a wholistic view

While simple on the surface, the underlying architecture sets the stage for powerful, future-ready logistics automation.

What This Means for Customers

 Faster, simpler access to operational intelligence

Users can ask Joule questions in natural language — no need to navigate complex screens or interpret multiple reports.

Immediate visibility where it matters most

Inventory and material readiness have direct impact on non-productive time.

A future-proof foundation for autonomous logistics

This first release is intentionally scoped — but designed for expansion into item receival, returns process, and more.

A clear step toward an “AI co-pilot” for upstream operations

Joule is not just a search tool. It is the beginning of a more intelligent, proactive, and predictive logistics environment.

Technical Highlights Behind the Scenes

While the customer experience focuses on simplicity, the technical implementation is sophisticated:

Flow Diagram

 
 

 

1. Semantic Understanding of FL and S/4HANA Operational Objects

Joule interprets upstream-specific structures such as:

  • Field Logistics items
  • PO, GR, Open and Return quantity
  • Latest Milestone
  • Non-stock Inventory availability data

This domain-awareness is what enables Joule to deliver precise, contextual answers.

2. Natural Language → CDS Query Generation

 

Joule automatically translates plain language into data retrieval operations using:

  • CDS consumption views
  • FL OData APIs

This eliminates the need for custom queries or separate analytical tool.

Functionality:

Do follow the below link to understand about Joule and how to access the same in a Private Cloud system.

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/joule-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-a-comprehensive-setup-guide/ba-p/13786453

Once you login to your Fiori system as a Supply Chain Analyst persona and click on the Joule icon at the top, all the capabilities that are part of your user role will be available. Users also can click on helpful conversation starters instead of asking a question.

Certain mandatory parameters are needed to process the user utterance, for our capability the item number/ description must be provided. Additionally, optional parameters like plant could also be provided to narrow down the search results.

Joule displays a list of items that are relevant for your search along with some important fields such as PO and item, Latest Milestone.

You can click on each entry which would take you to a detail view wherein additional fields such as Order and various quantities can be viewed.

Also, there is a button at the bottom which can be used to Navigate to Manage Logistics application that filters the data already entered by the user.

 

Customer-Focused Future Roadmap

SAP has already signalled a multi-release roadmap to expand Joule’s Oil and Gas capabilities beyond visibility into actionable intelligence and automated logistics execution.

The Future Vision

This progression reflects SAP’s commitment to controlled, safe, value-driven rollout of Joule capabilities to field logistics operations.

Conclusion: A Small Release with a Massive Strategic Horizon

The May 2025 Joule capability for FL may be limited to inventory visibility, but it represents:

  • The first-ever Joule release across industries
  • The foundation of AI-enriched S/4HANA FL operations
  • The beginning of SAP’s broader AI transformation across line-of-business functions

Customers leveraging this early capability are not just gaining a new feature—they are positioning themselves at the frontline of an industry-wide shift, where SAP systems evolve from transactional engines to intelligent co-pilots for complex field logistics operations.
